Title: CO5000 Teflon blade shifted and scraping conche wall
Question: The Teflon blade on the CO5000 conche has shifted about 1cm and is now scraping against the wall. It happened after unmelted drops entered the conche and caused violent shaking that bent the emulsifier shaft. What caused this and how do we fix it?
Answer: The violent shaking was caused by unmelted drops entering the conche, which bent the emulsifier shaft and shifted the Teflon/Derlin blade. The blade material is Teflon or Derlin. The CO5000 requires a minimum of 3000kg of chocolate to operate the emulsifier safely - running it with less product can cause similar issues. The emulsifier speed range is 25Hz minimum and 40-45Hz maximum. To fix: the emulsifier shaft needs to be straightened or replaced, and the blade repositioned. The safety door bypass (2 bridges in diagram) exists but is dangerous and not recommended.
Tags: CO5000, Teflon blade, scraping, emulsifier shaft, bent, unmelted drops, shaking, Derlin, minimum 3000kg

Title: Zinc anode sizing per machine type
Question: What size zinc anodes do we need for each machine? They all look different sizes.
Answer: Zinc anodes come in three sizes: the longest ones are for the conches, the smallest ones are for the mill reservoir, and the medium-sized ones are for the mill tanks. Each mill tank requires 2 anodes. The anodes protect against corrosion in the water circuit and should be replaced when significantly corroded.
Tags: zinc anodes, sizing, conche, mill reservoir, mill tank, corrosion protection

Title: Mobile pump preparation - flush first pass
Question: How should we prepare the mobile pump before transferring product?
Answer: Always flush the first pass from the mobile pump into a bucket for cleaning purposes. This removes any residual material or contaminants from the pump before connecting it to the production line. This is standard practice for maintaining product quality.
Tags: mobile pump, flush, cleaning, first pass, bucket

Title: Mill-50 water jacket leak from sight glass gaskets
Question: Our Mill-50 is leaking water from the reservoir sight glass area. Also, how does the auto-refill function work?
Answer: The water leak is coming from the sight glass gaskets on the reservoir. Replace the gaskets to stop the leak. Regarding auto-refill: the system has an EV solenoid valve and a manual fill valve. The auto-refill function can be set to 999 minutes with a 16-hour cycle interval. When activated, the solenoid opens periodically to top off the water jacket automatically. Make sure the manual fill valve is also accessible for manual top-ups when needed.
Tags: Mill-50, water jacket, leak, sight glass, gaskets, auto-refill, EV solenoid, 999 minutes, 16 hour cycle

Title: Mill-50 water temperature set too high
Question: Our Mill-50 water temp is set to 52°C with product at 55°C. Is this correct?
Answer: The water temperature is set too high. The recommended setting is 40°C for water and 45°C for product temperature for standard chocolate processing. For white chocolate, use 40°C water and 45°C product. There should always be a 5-10°C difference between water and product temperature settings. Setting the water too high reduces the cooling effectiveness and can lead to overheating issues.
Tags: Mill-50, water temperature, 52°C, too high, recommended 40°C water, 45°C product, white chocolate

Title: CO1000 emulsifier cooling fan not working
Question: The cooling fan on the CO1000 emulsifier motor is not running. The emulsifier motor itself works but the fan doesn't spin.
Answer: The emulsifier cooling fan has its own separate breaker in the electrical panel. Check if that breaker has tripped - this is a common oversight as it's separate from the main emulsifier motor breaker. The fan should always run whenever the emulsifier motor is on. Reset the breaker and the fan should start working again.
Tags: CO1000, emulsifier, cooling fan, separate breaker, tripped

Title: SOTU 600 new line - conche positioning with forklift
Question: We're installing the new SOTU 600 line. How should we position the conches?
Answer: Use a forklift to position the conches in place. For the uprighting technique when conches arrive on their side: use a crane with a crossbar lift. The rotation point should be on the legs to prevent the conche from swinging during the lift. Once upright, position with forklift into final location.
Tags: SOTU 600, conche, positioning, forklift, crane, crossbar, uprighting, rotation point

Title: SOTU 600 platform leveling and anti-vibration feet
Question: How do we level the platform for the SOTU 600 line installation?
Answer: The platform has anti-vibration feet with 1/2-inch thread for leveling adjustments. Turn the threaded feet to level the platform precisely. Use a level to ensure the platform is even across all mounting points. The mills are identical so placement (left/right) doesn't matter.
Tags: SOTU 600, platform, leveling, anti-vibration feet, 1/2 inch thread, mills identical

Title: SOTU 600 load cells and mixer placement
Question: Where are the load cells for the SOTU 600 mixer and how do we install them?
Answer: The load cells are in the accessories box that shipped with the equipment. Mount the load cells BEFORE placing the mixer on the platform - they go underneath the mixer feet. The discharge valve should be positioned on the right side. The electrical cabinet placement should allow access to all connections.
Tags: SOTU 600, load cells, accessories box, mixer, discharge valve, right side, electrical cabinet

Title: SOTU 600 compressed air requirements
Question: What are the compressed air requirements for the SOTU 600 line?
Answer: The air line should be 10mm connecting to the general cabinet on the right side. From there, the air distributes to all machines in the line. You can use a 1/4-inch thread fitting to connect to the main air supply. Ensure adequate pressure (minimum 7 bar / 100 PSI) at the gauge near the main electrical cabinet.
Tags: SOTU 600, compressed air, 10mm, general cabinet, right side, 1/4 inch fitting, 7 bar, 100 PSI

Title: Pizzato Safety Hinge Switch sticking on TK500CC
Question: The Pizzato safety hinge switch on the TK500CC tank keeps sticking. Sometimes it works when detached from the lid but not when mounted. Can we adjust the internal screw?
Answer: Try cleaning the switch with WD-40 first. The switch is not serviceable internally - there is no adjustable screw that will fix it. If cleaning doesn't resolve the sticking, the entire switch needs to be replaced. The switch only works properly when mounted correctly on the door with proper alignment. When the hinge doesn't go back far enough past 90° to reset, it indicates the switch mechanism is worn.
Tags: Pizzato, safety hinge switch, TK500CC, sticking, WD-40, not serviceable, replace

Title: Stirrer motor high-pitched hum fixed via VFD parameter
Question: The stirrer motor is making a high-pitched humming noise. What's causing it?
Answer: The high-pitched hum is caused by a VFD (Variable Frequency Drive) parameter setting. This can be adjusted remotely by Andrea to eliminate the noise. The Hz parameter needs to be changed in the VFD configuration. No physical repair is needed - it's purely an electronic setting adjustment.
Tags: stirrer motor, high-pitched hum, VFD, parameter, Hz, remote fix, Andrea

Title: T100 roaster internal support bars breaking off drum
Question: We found that internal support bars inside the T100 roaster drum have broken off. How do we inspect and fix this?
Answer: Check the welds on the internal support bars by looking through the access holes from outside the cylinder, as well as inspecting inside the drum directly. The bars break due to weld fatigue from the rotational forces of heavy bean loads (100kg+). All bars need to be rewelded using stainless steel welding rods for added material strength. Welds made without added material will crack again. This is a recurring issue if not properly addressed with stronger welds.
Tags: T100, roaster, support bars, broken, drum, welds, stainless steel, fatigue, reweld

Title: Chiller water connections - which port is inlet vs outlet
Question: How do we identify which port is the inlet and outlet on the chiller water connections?
Answer: The top connection is the water inlet (IN) and the bottom connection is the outlet (OUT). The yellow-black indicator valve marks the inlet side. Remember: top = in, bottom = out. The chiller system uses a heat exchanger with two separate circuits - the chiller glycol circuit and the machine water circuit do NOT mix. The mains water connection stays for the auto-refill solenoid function.
Tags: chiller, water connections, top inlet, bottom outlet, yellow-black indicator, heat exchanger, glycol, auto-refill

Title: Chiller system installation - heat exchanger dual circuits
Question: We're installing the chiller system. How does the heat exchanger work with the existing water circuit?
Answer: The heat exchanger has two separate circuits that do NOT mix: (1) the chiller glycol circuit, and (2) the machine water circuit. The mains water supply stays connected for the auto-refill solenoid to top off the machine water circuit. A software change is needed remotely to integrate the chiller with the machine controls - give Packint 2-3 days advance notice to schedule the remote programming change.
Tags: chiller, heat exchanger, two circuits, glycol, machine water, auto-refill, software change, remote programming

Title: CO5000 minimum chocolate level for emulsifier operation
Question: What's the minimum amount of chocolate needed in the CO5000 to run the emulsifier?
Answer: The CO5000 requires a minimum of 3000kg of chocolate to safely operate the emulsifier. You can run the stirrer without the emulsifier at lower chocolate levels. Running the emulsifier with insufficient product can cause violent shaking, bend the shaft, and shift the Teflon blade. The emulsifier speed range is 25Hz minimum to 40-45Hz maximum.
Tags: CO5000, minimum level, 3000kg, emulsifier, stirrer, speed range, 25Hz, 40-45Hz

Title: Ball mill pump clog with allulose recipe
Question: The Mill-50 pump is clogging when processing a recipe with allulose. The product turns into a concrete-like mass. We've made this recipe before without issues.
Answer: The clog is likely caused by humidity in the allulose ingredient. When allulose absorbs moisture, it can cause the product to harden into a concrete-like consistency that blocks the pump. Check the ingredient packaging - open or improperly stored packages absorb humidity. The same recipe can produce different results depending on ingredient humidity levels. Ensure all ingredients, especially allulose, are stored in sealed containers and check for moisture before use.
Tags: Mill-50, pump clog, allulose, humidity, concrete, blockage, ingredient storage, moisture

Title: CO250 liquid sensor not activating
Question: The liquid sensor on the CO250 isn't activating. What should we check?
Answer: Check the connector connections to the sensor and ensure they are properly seated. Clean the sensor head - contamination can prevent proper readings. The liquid sensor switches the position of the 3-way valve. If the sensor detects product, it switches the valve to allow flow; if it doesn't detect product, the valve stays in the default position. Also check the wiring continuity from the sensor to the control panel.
Tags: CO250, liquid sensor, connector, clean sensor head, 3-way valve, wiring

Title: Mill-50 pump can't push canola oil to conche
Question: The Mill-50 pump can't push canola oil 7 feet up to the conche. The oil is too thin/fluid for the pump to move.
Answer: Canola oil is too low viscosity for the positive displacement pump to effectively push it vertically. Add sugar and 0.05% lecithin to increase viscosity so the pump can grip the product. Important: do NOT run sugar through the system without lecithin for more than 15 minutes, as dry sugar will damage the pump seals and create excessive friction.
Tags: Mill-50, pump, canola oil, low viscosity, add sugar, 0.05% lecithin, 15 minutes max without lecithin

Title: CO250 pump shafts not turning - sheared pinion pins
Question: The CO250 pump motor runs but the pump shafts don't turn. What's wrong?
Answer: The pins on the stub shaft have sheared, disconnecting the motor from the pump mechanism. A replacement pinion needs to be ordered from Italy. To remove the pump cover: use the alternating extraction pegs, turning 90° at a time to evenly extract it. The pump lobes can be removed using M12 bolts as a puller. The gearbox uses GADUS S2 V220 2 grease (250g capacity). Until the replacement pinion arrives, the pump cannot be operated.
Tags: CO250, pump shafts, pinion, sheared pins, stub shaft, extraction pegs, 90 degrees, M12 bolts, GADUS S2 V220 2, 250g

Title: Melting tank motor oil leak between motor and gearbox
Question: The melting tank motor is leaking oil. How do we determine if it's mechanical oil vs cocoa butter?
Answer: The leak is from the oil seal located between the motor shaft and the gearbox. To confirm it's mechanical oil and not cocoa butter: collect a sample, let it cool, and taste test it. Black residue on the shaft is normal grease and not indicative of a problem. The oil seals need to be replaced. Packint shipped 2 replacement oil seals under warranty with a tutorial for replacement.
Tags: melting tank, motor, oil leak, oil seal, gearbox, taste test, warranty, replacement seals

Title: SOTU 600 line cycle stopped after 5 minutes - air pressure alarm
Question: The SOTU 600 line stopped after running for only 5 minutes. It showed an air pressure/valve alarm.
Answer: Check the air pressure at the gauge near the main electrical cabinet - it must be at minimum 100 PSI / 7 bar. For manual transfer when the auto cycle is interrupted, open valves in this order: 5-14-13-9 (valve 11 always stays open). Start equipment in this sequence: stirrer mixer → pump mill2 → stirrer mill2 → pump mill1 → stirrer mill1 → pump mixer. This sequence ensures product flows from the end of the line backward to prevent overflow.
Tags: SOTU 600, air pressure, valve alarm, 100 PSI, 7 bar, manual transfer, valves 5-14-13-9, valve 11

Title: Auto mode adding sugar to finished chocolate - 2kg recipe trick
Question: We need to run the SOTU 600 auto cycle on product already in the mixer without loading new ingredients. How?
Answer: Use the 2kg recipe workaround: set all ingredients to 2kg in the recipe. Since the weight already in the mixer exceeds 2kg for each ingredient, the system will skip the loading phase and go directly to the mix time. Then set your desired refining time and the auto cycle will process the existing product without trying to load additional ingredients.
Tags: SOTU 600, auto mode, 2kg recipe, workaround, skip loading, existing product, refining time

Title: Recipe parameter storage in PLC - modification request
Question: Can we store recipe parameters including process settings (not just ingredient weights) in the PLC?
Answer: Normally the PLC only stores recipe ingredient weights, and the operator sets process parameters (temperatures, times, speeds) per batch. However, Packint agreed to modify the software and touch screen to include process parameters in saved recipes. This modification is being provided free of charge. The modification requires Packint's software engineer to update both the PLC program and touch screen interface. Schedule the remote update with 2-3 days advance notice.
Tags: recipe parameters, PLC, process settings, software modification, free of charge, remote update

Title: Ball mill safety relay failure after power outage
Question: After a power outage the ball mill shows an emergency button alarm and nothing works. The OMRON G9SB-200-D safety relay appears to have failed.
Answer: To diagnose: bridge terminals T11-T12 and T21-T22 on the safety relay to test if the relay is the problem (NOT T11-T21 and T12-T22 - that's incorrect). If the valves start working with the bridge in place, the relay is faulty. To further test: disconnect wire from terminal 13 (wire 01) and connect it to the wire on terminal 14 (wire 1) - connect these two wires together to exclude the safety relay. To eliminate the emergency alarm signal, connect wire from terminal 23 to terminal 24. The relay costs approximately €205 and ships from Italy (about 5 business days). The OMRON G9SB-200-D has no reset function - if contacts fail, the entire relay must be replaced. Also check for loose wires, particularly under the Yaskawa drive at L2.
Source: Packint Tech Support - Giacomo, Alvaro, Martina
Tags: safety relay, OMRON G9SB-200-D, emergency button, T11-T12, T21-T22, bridge terminals, €205, power outage, Yaskawa, loose wire

Title: Safety relay replacement procedure - wiring walkthrough
Question: We have the replacement OMRON safety relay. How do we wire it correctly? The number labels on the wires look like 7s but are actually 1s.
Answer: Follow the relay connection diagram provided by Giacomo. Key notes: numbers that look like '7' are actually '1', and numbers that look like '3179' are actually '3/19'. The relay connects to the e-stop and auxiliary power (blue button). Wire connections are at positions 3/16-3/17 (blue button) and 3/18-3/19, 3/20-3/21. Remove all black jumpers - only use the red wires. Switched 1 goes to terminal 23 on top, second wire to terminal 14 on bottom. After installation, if it still shows the fault: check voltage between wires 01 and 2 - should read 24VAC (not DC). Input voltage at the panel should be 208V across phases. A loose wire under breaker Q3 was the root cause in one case - wire 2 was loose under Q3. After tightening and resetting Q3, the alarm cleared.
Source: Packint Tech Support - Giacomo, Chris Baker
Tags: safety relay, OMRON, wiring, 24VAC, Q3 breaker, loose wire, blue button, e-stop, relay diagram

Title: Melting tank capacity - no visual fill indicator
Question: Is there a visual indicator for the 1000kg capacity on the melting tanks?
Answer: No, there is no visual fill indicator on the melting tanks. Each side holds 1000kg maximum, with max fill being nearly to the melting grate. If you've lost track of the quantity, the best option is to melt more butter. Even if you have the exact amount needed, you need at least 75-100kg extra to ensure there's enough product to fill the vertical pipe going up from the tank to the mixer. Don't let the tank get near empty while transferring - less product means less flow to the pump and longer transfer times.
Tags: melting tank, 1000kg, capacity, no indicator, melting grate, 75-100kg extra, vertical pipe

Title: Manual butter addition when running low on supply
Question: Our cocoa butter supplier is delayed and we only have 95kg in the melter. Can we manually add butter and run a 550kg batch?
Answer: Yes, you can set the butter weight to zero in the recipe and add the butter manually to the mixer. The auto cycle will skip the butter loading phase since it's set to zero. You may need to manually transfer the butter from the melter to the mixer if using the pump, or add it directly. Note that without using the conche (volume too small for effective conching), this is a temporary solution for production continuity.
Tags: manual butter, zero recipe, low supply, skip loading, 550kg batch, temporary solution

Title: Decrystallizer internal structure and clog investigation
Question: We believe there's a clog inside the decrystallizer. Can you provide an internal diagram and explain the structure?
Answer: The decrystallizer has an inner cylinder with 3/4-inch tubes running straight through it. To access the tubes, remove the two cones at each end. The tubes run in a straight line through the cylinder. The internal structure is identical between different line models - only the lengths may vary. To drain the decrystallizer for disconnection: open the purple drain valve under the heater tank. Note that some water will remain in the circuit even after draining - you'll need to open a tube connected to the cylinder to remove all remaining water.
Tags: decrystallizer, internal structure, 3/4 inch tubes, cones, drain valve, clog, purple valve

Title: Conche 2 ball valve stuck - won't open with actuator
Question: The 3-way ball valve on Conche 2 (CO5000) won't open. The actuator moves but the ball valve itself is stuck. Even manually with a wrench it requires extreme force.
Answer: The ball valve requires tremendous leverage to open manually. It opens counter-clockwise 90°. The notches/lines on the valve show the direction of the openings in the ball. To troubleshoot: (1) Remove the 4 bolts to remove the pneumatic actuator. (2) Try manually turning the valve stem with a wrench - if it won't turn, the valve is stuck internally. (3) The valve can be disassembled by unscrewing the nut to access the sphere for cleaning with hot water and high pressure. However, the sphere cannot be fully removed as it was inserted with a special machine. If cleaning doesn't resolve the resistance, the entire valve needs to be replaced. Packint can ship a replacement. For immediate transfer: manually leave the valve open and use the pump to transfer chocolate, monitoring the level sensor to stop the pump manually when the tank is full.
Tags: ball valve, stuck, CO5000, Conche 2, actuator, counter-clockwise, 90 degrees, replacement, 4 bolts, sphere, hot water

Title: Tank level sensor testing during manual valve operation
Question: If we manually leave the conche ball valve open, will the level sensor still stop the pump?
Answer: The level sensor should still stop the pump even with the valve manually held open. However, this is not guaranteed since the valve will still register as closed in the system. Before relying on this: test the level sensor by touching the probes with your hand or a metal object while the pump is running. If touching the probes causes the pump to stop, you can safely leave the pump running and the conche will keep the tank full automatically.
Tags: level sensor, test, probes, manual valve, pump stop, touch test, metal object

Title: Pump seal tightening procedure for chocolate pumps
Question: How do we maintain and tighten the chocolate pump seals?
Answer: Packint provides a detailed PDF procedure for tightening pump seals. The seals use teflon gaskets that need uniform tightening. Key points: (1) Tighten evenly around the circumference to ensure uniform compression. (2) This is ongoing maintenance - the teflon wears over time and needs periodic retightening. (3) The seal life depends on tightening accuracy and can last several years with proper maintenance. (4) When the teflon gasket can no longer be tightened further, it needs to be replaced entirely. (5) If a pump leaks, check the seal tightening first before assuming a bigger problem.
Tags: pump seals, tightening, teflon gasket, uniform, maintenance, PDF procedure

Title: Conche water circuit isolation and refill for valve removal
Question: How do we isolate the water system to remove a ball valve from the conche, and how do we refill afterward?
Answer: Step 1: Turn off the conche water pump. Step 2: Disconnect the 1/2-inch water pipes from the valve. Step 3: Remove the actuator (4 × 8Ma bolts). Step 4: Unscrew the valve flange bolts. The water circuit is open (not pressurized), so there's no air to bleed when refilling. After reinstalling the valve and reconnecting all 1/2-inch water pipes: turn on the water pump and heater. If water was lost from the circuit, use the EV button on the touch screen to refill. This must be done only after all pipes are reconnected and the water pump is turned back on.
Tags: water circuit, isolation, valve removal, 1/2 inch pipes, 8Ma bolts, refill, EV button, water pump

Title: SOTU 600 auto cycle stops unexpectedly mid-run
Question: The SOTU 600 stopped at 30 minutes into a 170-minute refining cycle with no error messages showing. It resumed when we pressed start.
Answer: If the cycle stops and resumes from the same time (no reset) when start is pressed, this behaves like a pause - equivalent to the start-pause button being pressed. If no one was near the machine, check for: (1) accidental button press, (2) vibration activating the touch screen, (3) a brief power fluctuation. Monitor the remaining cycle time and check pump speeds and mill product levels. If it happens again, clean the touch screen as dirt can cause phantom touches.
Tags: SOTU 600, auto cycle, stops, no error, pause, resume, phantom touch

Title: Conche pump protection - amperage not pressure based
Question: Does the conche pump have a pressure relief valve? What triggers the fault?
Answer: The pump does not read pressure - it uses a frequency converter (VFD) that monitors motor amperage. When the motor draws too many amps, the VFD triggers a fault and stops the pump. There is no PRV (pressure relief valve) in the system. The set amp limit triggers a shutdown to protect the motor. If you get a pump fault, it's an overcurrent condition typically caused by thick product or a blockage.
Tags: conche pump, amperage, VFD, frequency converter, no PRV, overcurrent, motor protection

Title: Magnetic filter leaking chocolate
Question: What would cause the magnetic trap/filter to leak chocolate even though the filter basket is not blocked?
Answer: Check that: (1) the basket is in the correct position inside the filter housing, (2) the lid gasket is not damaged, and (3) the lid is closed properly. If the pipe is not blocked and the lid is sealed correctly, no chocolate should escape from the filter. A misaligned basket or damaged gasket are the most common causes of leaking.
Tags: magnetic filter, leak, basket position, lid gasket, sealed

Title: Ball valve cleaning procedure - remove flange and clean sphere
Question: How do we clean a stuck ball valve that won't turn even after removing the actuator?
Answer: With the valve removed from the line: (1) Unscrew the nut on the valve body to remove the flange. (2) This exposes the outside of the sphere for cleaning. (3) Clean with hot water and high air pressure. (4) The sphere cannot be fully removed - it was inserted with a special machine at the factory. (5) Block the valve body with a clamp for leverage when trying to rotate the stem. If cleaning doesn't resolve the sticking, the valve must be replaced. Packint can check stock and ship a replacement 3-way valve.
Tags: ball valve, cleaning, flange removal, sphere, hot water, air pressure, clamp, replacement

Title: SOTU 600 max level alarms - pump speed adjustments
Question: We keep getting max level alarms on both mills during auto cycle. The pumps seem to push more chocolate than the downstream equipment can process.
Answer: When starting auto cycle, set Mixer and Mill1 pump speeds to 45Hz, leave Mill2 at 60Hz. The pumps auto-adjust speed based on level sensors in auto mode. Key parameters in ADV PAR: 'sec alarm MAX Level' (30 sec delay before alarm), 'Sec stop Pump after Max level' (2 sec delay to restart pump after max level). Always start auto cycle with MILLS empty - never transfer chocolate manually between mills during auto cycle. If you get max level alarm: switch to manual, lower chocolate in both mills below sensors, clean the sensor forks, then restart auto. Every new auto cycle should start with pump speeds set to 60Hz (or per recommendation based on recipe viscosity).
Tags: SOTU 600, max level alarm, pump speed, 45Hz, 60Hz, ADV PAR, level sensors, auto cycle, clean forks

Title: Inverter pump fault - reset procedure
Question: We're getting 'fault inverter pump' errors. What does this mean and how do we fix it?
Answer: The inverter (VFD) fault means the pump motor is drawing too many amps, likely due to thick/sticky product or a mechanical blockage. To reset: turn off the entire electrical panel for at least 2 minutes, then turn it back on. This resets the inverter alarm. The max amp limit for the pumps is approximately 9A. If the fault persists after reset, the product may be too viscous - try adding cocoa butter to reduce viscosity or lower the pump speed. Also check for tripped breakers in the electrical panel.
Tags: inverter fault, VFD, pump, reset, 2 minutes, electrical panel, 9A max, viscosity, breaker

Title: Mill temperature discrepancy between identical settings
Question: Both mills have the same temperature settings but one shows dramatically different temps. Mill2 water temp dropped to 21°C while Mill1 stays at 42°C.
Answer: Check the heat exchanger valve operation on the cooler mill. The exchanger may be continuously cooling due to a stuck valve. To verify: (1) Press the EXC button on the touch screen for each mill and check if the exchanger valve physically rotates, OR (2) set a lower product temperature than current reading and see if the valve activates. Also check water inlet and outlet temperatures at the exchanger. If the valve works (you can hear/see it rotate), the issue may be with the chiller circuit - check water flow rate and glycol temperature at the exchanger inlet.
Tags: mill temperature, discrepancy, exchanger valve, EXC button, water flow, chiller circuit, glycol

Title: SOTU 600 remote monitored production - diagnosis and fix
Question: After a remote monitoring session, Packint found and fixed the issue causing pump shutdowns and level sensor alarms. What was the problem?
Answer: The issue was water temperature protection parameters. During the original installation, the cooling water temperatures were different than the current operational temperatures, so the protection mode thresholds were set incorrectly. When the chiller water got cold enough during production, it triggered the temperature protection which stopped the pumps. Packint remotely modified the temperature protection parameters so they no longer interfere with pump operation during the auto cycle. It is critical to maintain constant chiller water conditions going forward - if you change the chiller settings, Packint may need to readjust the temperature protection parameters again.
Tags: SOTU 600, remote monitoring, temperature protection, chiller water, pump shutdown, parameter modification

Title: SOTU 600 sugar loading before fats - recipe and tare issue
Question: The SOTU 600 is loading sugar before cocoa butter and mass, which is the wrong order. The sugar feeder activates first instead of the liquids.
Answer: This happens when the recipe or tare weight is incorrect. Check: (1) The tare of the mixer must be set correctly (should be approximately 4kg for empty mixer). (2) Verify the recipe weights match your production sheet. (3) If the mixer already has weight in it that the system doesn't account for, it thinks the liquid ingredients are already loaded and skips to sugar. Re-tare the mixer when empty, reload the recipe, and start the auto cycle fresh.
Tags: SOTU 600, sugar loading order, tare, recipe, weight, mixer, auto cycle

Title: Leaving chocolate in mills overnight causes separation and high amps
Question: After leaving chocolate in the mills overnight, the stirrer draws high amps and triggers inverter protection. Why?
Answer: Leaving chocolate unstirred in the mills overnight causes separation - the cocoa butter rises to the top while solids settle to the bottom. This creates a thick sticky mass at the bottom. When you start the stirrer, it hits this heavy mass and draws excessive amps, triggering the inverter protection. This is NOT a machine malfunction - it's a protection against the abnormal load. To recover: lower the stirrer speed until it can move the mass without alarming (try 35Hz, then 30Hz if needed). Once the product is remixed and flowing, gradually increase speed. Strong recommendation: never leave chocolate unstirred in the mills overnight. If production must stop, transfer product to the conche or mixer where it can be stirred.
Tags: overnight, chocolate separation, high amps, inverter protection, stirrer, cocoa butter rises, solids settle, lower speed

Title: SOTU 600 pump buttons delayed response on touch screen
Question: During auto cycle, pump buttons on the touch screen have a delayed response - they activate minutes after being pressed instead of immediately.
Answer: Clean the touch screen thoroughly - dirt and chocolate residue can cause phantom touches and delayed inputs. The touch screen does not work like a computer with input queuing. If buttons appear unresponsive, don't press them multiple times as each press registers and will execute later. Also check: (1) water and product temperatures must not be too low (pumps won't operate in manual if temps are below minimum), (2) level sensor forks must be clean, (3) verify the cycle selector is in the correct mode (MAN vs AUT).
Tags: touch screen, delayed response, pump buttons, clean screen, phantom touch, MAN, AUT selector

Title: TK500 safety hinge switch cable replacement - finding the splice
Question: How do we replace the safety hinge switch cable on the TK500 tank? The cable changes from black to grey partway.
Answer: The cable is spliced along the path from the switch to the terminal block because the switch cable isn't long enough to reach directly. Follow this procedure: (1) Disconnect the old cable at the terminal block inside the electrical panel. (2) Follow the grey sheath from the panel toward the tank. (3) The splice is inside the grey sheath between the tank crosspiece and the electrical panel. (4) You must remove the old cable to route the new one. (5) Leave the grey cable section connected to the terminal block and reconnect the new switch cable to the splice point. An electrician may be helpful as accessing the cable route can be complex.
Tags: safety hinge switch, cable, splice, TK500, grey sheath, terminal block, electrician

Title: CO1000 conche used as temporary holding tank
Question: Can we use the CO1000 conche as a temporary heated holding tank?
Answer: Yes, you can use the CO1000 conche as a storage/holding tank to maintain chocolate at a set temperature. The TK500 tank has an internal overflow with a drain under the tank. The 1000kg tank has an overflow on the upper side. Both have open water circuits (no pressurization). Simply set the desired temperature and let the stirrer run to keep the chocolate fluid and at temperature.
Tags: CO1000, holding tank, temporary storage, temperature, set temp, overflow

Title: SOTU 600 emulsifier start weight setting
Question: When should the SOTU 600 emulsifier start during the loading process?
Answer: Set the emulsifier start weight to at least 500kg (not 350kg as may be default). Starting the emulsifier too early with insufficient product in the mixer can cause damage or ineffective emulsification. Also ensure melters are always fully stocked - running production with partially filled melters causes excessively long ingredient loading times.
Tags: SOTU 600, emulsifier, start weight, 500kg, melter, loading time

Title: SOTU 600 lecithin loading method during auto cycle
Question: When and how should we load lecithin during the SOTU 600 auto cycle?
Answer: Load lecithin directly through the mixer door grid while the auto cycle is running - there is no need to stop/pause the cycle. Open the mixer door and pour the lecithin through the grid. If you pause the cycle to add lecithin, the mixer agitator also stops, which is unnecessary. The lecithin incorporates quickly with the stirrer running.
Tags: SOTU 600, lecithin, loading, mixer door, grid, no pause needed, auto cycle

Title: SOTU 600 sampling during refining without stopping
Question: How do we take a product sample during refining without interrupting the auto cycle?
Answer: Take the sample from the pipe that goes from the Mixer to Mill 1. Open the Mill 1 door to access the pipe while the cycle continues. Note: opening the door will stop the Mill 1 stirrer (safety interlock), but the rest of the cycle continues. Set a longer refining time than expected (e.g., 100 min instead of 70) to give yourself time to test and decide whether to continue refining or start the automatic unloading phase. You can adjust the unloading time while the cycle is running.
Tags: SOTU 600, sampling, refining, pipe, mixer to mill1, door interlock, adjust time

Title: Hopper breaker tripping on SOTU 600 processing line
Question: Breaker 15Q1 tripped during operation. What does it connect to?
Answer: Breaker 15Q1 connects to the hopper/vibrator motor. If it trips: (1) Check that the hopper is not clogged with product. (2) Verify the motor is not hot (could indicate overload). (3) Check input voltage is correct. (4) Take a photo of the breaker's adjustment wheel setting and send to Packint for review. The adjustment wheel may need to be set higher if the hopper load is causing nuisance trips.
Tags: 15Q1 breaker, hopper, vibrator, motor, tripped, adjustment wheel

Title: Dry feeder loading sequence for SOTU 600
Question: Which dry feeder loads first - powder or sugar?
Answer: The loading sequence is: Powder (#1, left hopper) loads first, then Sugar (#2, right hopper). The sequence matches the PLC display layout left-to-right. When splitting ingredients between two hoppers, ensure each hopper has the correct weight programmed. If only one hopper has weight programmed but the total amount is split between both, you'll need to manually load the second portion or adjust the recipe.
Tags: dry feeder, sequence, powder first, sugar second, left right, PLC display

Title: Mill and mixer pump speed settings for SOTU 600
Question: What speed should the pumps be set to when starting?
Answer: Set pumps to 50Hz for standard operation. In auto mode, the pumps auto-adjust based on level sensors but don't change the set value on the touch screen - the system manages speed internally. The minimum auto-adjusted speed is 30Hz in auto mode. Below 30Hz, pumps can be damaged from insufficient flow. Do NOT manually set pump speeds below 30Hz. For each new auto cycle, verify pump speeds are properly set before starting.
Tags: pump speed, 50Hz, auto-adjust, level sensors, 30Hz minimum, SOTU 600

Title: Ball valve position indicator on conche valves
Question: How do I know if the ball valve on the conche is open or closed?
Answer: The arrow indicator on the valve shows the flow direction. Place the arrow in the position marked in the reference photo from Giacomo. When the arrow aligns with the pipe direction, the valve is open. The 3-way valve has two positions: one directs flow to the tank, the other allows recirculation back into the conche.
Tags: ball valve, position indicator, arrow, open, closed, 3-way valve, flow direction

Title: Mill-50 water pump replacement - VFD tripping resolved
Question: Just installed the new water pump on the Mill-50 but the VFD keeps tripping. What's wrong?
Answer: The jumper for the motor poles was reversed. Once the jumper polarity was corrected, the VFD stopped tripping. After correcting this, if the pump still won't start even though the 'pump on' switch lights up: check if the VFD is faulted without showing an error code. Reset the drive by power cycling it. The motor should free-spool when unpowered, confirming it's not locked up mechanically.
Source: Packint Tech Support - Giacomo, Hunter Peterson
Tags: Mill-50, water pump, VFD, tripping, jumper poles, reversed, drive fault, reset

Title: SOTU 600 valve 14c position for mill-to-mixer transfer
Question: What is the correct setting for valve 14c (between Mill 1 and Mill 2) to route product from Mill 1 back to the mixer?
Answer: The valve icon on the PLC screen may appear incorrectly rotated. Check the physical valve position - the 3-way valve directs flow either from Mill1 to Mill2 or from Mill1 back to the mixer depending on position. Verify by watching the actual flow direction after toggling the valve.
Tags: SOTU 600, valve 14c, Mill1, Mill2, mixer, 3-way valve, PLC icon

Title: Thick chocolate without lecithin causing SOTU 600 pump issues
Question: We're making chocolate without sunflower lecithin for a client. The mills keep getting max level alarms and the chocolate is very thick.
Answer: Without lecithin, the chocolate is much more viscous. The pumps slow down to compensate, which can cause the upstream mill to fill faster than the downstream equipment can process. Solutions: (1) Increase fat content (cocoa butter) significantly - 19% may not be enough. (2) If max level alarms occur, manually transfer from Mill2 to conche first, then Mill1 to Mill2. (3) Reduce pump speeds on Mixer (45Hz) and Mill1 (45Hz), keep Mill2 at 60Hz. (4) Consider adding additional 20kg cocoa butter if viscosity is causing persistent issues. (5) Transfer thick product out of mills before it sits - the longer it sits, the thicker it gets.
Tags: no lecithin, thick chocolate, viscosity, max level alarm, pump speed, cocoa butter, 45Hz, SOTU 600

Title: Electrical panel door key missing for Mill 2
Question: We can't open the electrical panel door on Mill 2 - we never received keys. How do we get in?
Answer: There are no spare keys available. To open the locked door: unscrew the knob/lock cylinder to remove it. This gives you access to the panel. A new replacement knob can be ordered if needed. In the future, ensure keys are accounted for during machine commissioning and installation.
Tags: electrical panel, key, missing, unscrew knob, Mill 2, lock

Title: SOTU 600 refining time extension during auto cycle
Question: If the chocolate needs more refining time and we miss the window to adjust, how do we extend it?
Answer: While in auto mode, you can increase the refining time at any point before it reaches zero. For example: if set to 100 minutes and at 95 minutes you test and it needs more time, change to 110 minutes before the timer expires. The cycle continues running. If the timer has already expired and the cycle stopped, set all ingredient weights to zero, set the new refining time, and restart the auto cycle - it will process the existing product without loading new ingredients.
Tags: SOTU 600, refining time, extend, auto cycle, zero ingredients, timer

Title: Liquor melter maximum temperature setting
Question: What is the maximum temperature we should set for the liquor/cocoa mass melter?
Answer: The melter can be set up to 50°C for cocoa mass/liquor. Setting it higher can help melt large volumes faster, but the standard operating range is typically around 50°C. Ensure all mass is fully melted and liquid before starting production on the SOTU 600 line - partially melted chunks entering the system cause problems.
Tags: liquor melter, maximum temperature, 50°C, cocoa mass, melting
